Key Match Events: Malik Monk led the way with a game-high 31 points
Jaylen Wells scored 30 points for Memphis
Six Kings players finished in double digits
Trey Lyles hit three triples in the first quarter
Devin Carter made his debut and showcased his defensive intensity, rebounding, and ability to push the fastbreak
The Kings outscored Memphis 102-100 in the final quarter
Scottie Pippen Jr. hit a three-pointer to give the Grizzlies the lead
DeMar DeRozan hit a three-pointer to put the Kings back up 4 points
Malik Monk hit a step back three to give the Kings a 10 point lead with 4:21 left
Pre-Game Insights: The Doug Christie era is off to a good start
Coach Christie emphasized the importance of strong perimeter defense
Keegan Murray was once again unavailable
Keon Ellis started against a bigger, more physical Grizzlies team
The Kings opted for a smaller but quicker lineup
DeMar DeRozan was expected to get more open three-point looks
Post-Match Reflections: The Kings played with joy and leaned into their strengths from start to finish
The game was a team effort with strong performances from multiple players
The team is expected to carry this momentum forward
The Kings will look to extend their winning streak on Sunday against the Golden State Warriors
Miscellaneous Highlights: Devin Carter made his debut and had a solid performance
Jaylen Wells had a fan contingent and a career-high performance
Zach Edey showed promise with a good touch in the post
Memphis has depth pieces that could be valuable for the Kings
Others: The Kings outshot Memphis from three-point range (44.7% vs 38.1%)
The Kings were without Keegan Murray
De' Aaron Fox struggled with shooting but had a solid game overall
The game was fast and frenetic from the start
The Kings outrebounded the Grizzlies in the first quarter but not in subsequent quarters
The Kings had a significant free throw advantage (21-36)
